WorkItem.Description: This is not exactly an issue or bug, it is more of a suggestion. Sometimes you start doing optimizations that take a long time (Build Upgrade List, for example) and it would be nice to have the option to pause it or at least get a confirmation box after you click the [Cancel] button (which would serve as a pseudo-pause).

Comments.Message:
As a workaround in the mean time, you can goto Task Manager, right click on Rawr.exe, and set the Priority to Low. I do that while raiding, and it *effectively* pauses the calculations because it doesn't slow down any other programs (it'll still calculate, slowly, if nothing else is using your CPU).

But yeah, a way to programmatically do that, and to outright pause it, is definitely on my list of things to add.
yes, a 'run in low priority' option for the optimizer/upgrade list generator would be very handy.  thanks
Another function that would benefit from this would be an item cache update.

At least you can cancel the optimiser.  Updating the cache takes my PC at work more than 2 hours and the only way to cancel it is to force the Task Manager to close it.   A cancel button would be fantastic (hopefully coming with Rawr3 at least)
The worst part is that the Update Item Cache has a Cancel button right there, it just doesn't DO anything!  It gets your hopes up, and then WHAM, crushes 'em!
Bumping this item: it would be very useful to have a default Optimizer priority (Windows scheduler) below Normal. Or at least a permanent user option to set it lower than Normal. Thanks!
Bumping this item: it would be very useful to have a default Optimizer priority (Windows scheduler) below Normal. Or at least a permanent user option to set it lower than Normal. Thanks!

Allowing John Average Doe to mess around with priority settings is not a good idea.  Long duration calculations should not be set to normal priority however. They should be 'Below normal' at max.  Ideal would be to set it to "above idle".  I don't know how the threads interact with the .NET garbage collector and system background tasks though, so there may be a reason it needs to be 'normal'.
